passage: Photosynthesis and cellular respiration are complementary processes that create a cycle of energy in ecosystems. Organisms break down glucose in the presence of oxygen to release energy, producing carbon dioxide and water as byproducts: C6H12O6 + 6O2 → 6CO2 + 6H2O + energy (ATP). passage: Plate tectonics is the scientific theory that Earth's outer shell is divided into several large plates that glide over the mantle, the rocky inner layer above the core. The plates act like a hard shell compared to Earth's mantle. This theory explains the occurrence of earthquakes, volcanic activity, mountain formation, and ocean trench creation. There are three types of plate boundaries: divergent boundaries where plates move apart (like the Mid-Atlantic Ridge), convergent boundaries where plates collide (like where the Indian Plate meets the Eurasian Plate, forming the Himalayas), and transform boundaries where plates slide past each other (like the San Andreas Fault in California). The movement of these plates occurs at a rate of a few centimeters per year, approximately the same rate at which fingernails grow.

passage: DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is the hereditary material in humans and most other organisms. Nearly every cell in a person's body has the same DNA, most of which is located in the cell nucleus. DNA consists of two long chains of nucleotides twisted into a double helix structure, first described by James Watson and Francis Crick in 1953, though their work built upon X-ray crystallography images produced by Rosalind Franklin. Each nucleotide contains a phosphate group, a sugar group, and one of four nitrogen bases: adenine (A), thymine (T), guanine (G), or cytosine (C). The sequence of these bases determines the information for building and maintaining an organism, similar to how letters form words and sentences. DNA replicates by separating into two strands, each serving as a template for creating a new complementary strand, following the base-pairing rules: A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

passage: Vaccines work by training the immune system to recognize and combat pathogens, either viruses or bacteria, before actual infection occurs. A vaccine contains weakened or inactive parts of a particular organism (antigen) that triggers an immune response. When the immune system encounters these antigens, it produces antibodies - proteins that specifically target and neutralize the pathogen. Importantly, the immune system also creates memory cells that 'remember' the pathogen. If the body is later exposed to the actual disease-causing organism, the immune system can quickly mobilize these memory cells to produce antibodies rapidly, preventing illness or reducing its severity. This principle of immunological memory forms the basis of vaccination programs worldwide and has led to the eradication of smallpox and near-elimination of diseases like polio and measles in many countries.

passage: The water crisis refers to the global situation where available fresh water resources are insufficient to meet demand. Although 71% of Earth's surface is covered by water, only 2.5% is fresh water, and most of that is locked in glaciers and ice caps. Less than 1% of the world's fresh water is readily accessible for human use. The crisis manifests in several ways: physical water scarcity affects regions like the Middle East and North Africa where water resources are insufficient for population needs; economic water scarcity occurs where water exists but infrastructure to access it is inadequate, common in sub-Saharan Africa; and water pollution reduces the amount of safe water available. Contributing factors include population growth, agricultural irrigation (which accounts for 70% of freshwater use), industrial consumption, and climate change affecting precipitation patterns. Solutions require integrated approaches including improved irrigation efficiency, water recycling, desalination technology, better watershed management, and reducing water pollution.
